chapter.title: Compute API (CURRENT)
chapter.para: This documentation supports the API v2.1 base version. If all extensions are enabled, the Compute API v1.1 and v2.0 requests and responses match the API v2.1 requests and responses.

Each API version lists its required extensions for the full request and responses to be available. API v2.1 must enable all extensions all the time. It uses micro-version headers to expose any additional functionality.

note.para: Effective in the OpenStack Kilo release, XML support in requests and responses was removed for the Compute API.

chapter.para: For details about the Compute API, see the Compute API.

section.title: API versions
section.para: Lists information for all API versions.

section.title: Servers (servers)
section.para: Lists, creates, gets details for, updates, and deletes servers.

When you create a server, you can specify a password through the optional adminPass attribute. The password must meet the complexity requirements set by your OpenStack Compute provider. The server might enter an ERROR state if the complexity requirements are not met. In this case, a client might issue a change password action to reset the server password.

If you do not specify a password, the API generates and assigns a random password that it returns in the response object. This password is guaranteed to meet the security requirements set by the compute provider. For security reasons, the password is not returned in subsequent &GET; calls.

You can specify custom server metadata at server launch time. The maximum size for each metadata key-value pair is 255 bytes. The compute provider determines the maximum number of key-value pairs that can be supplied for each server. You can query this value through the maxServerMeta absolute limit.
You can specify one or more networks to which the server connects at launch time. Users can also specify a specific port on the network or the fixed IP address to assign to the server interface.

note.para: You can use both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses as access addresses and you can assign both addresses simultaneously. You can update access addresses after you create a server.

section.para: To customize the personality of a server instance, you can inject data into its file system. For example, you might insert ssh keys, set configuration files, or store data that you want to retrieve from inside the instance. This customization method provides minimal launch-time personalization. If you require significant customization, create a custom image.
Follow these guidelines when you inject files:

listitem.para: The maximum size of the file path data is 255 bytes.
Encode the file contents as a Base64 string. The compute provider determines the maximum size of the file contents. This value can vary based on the image that is used to create the server.

note.para: The maximum limit refers to the number of bytes in the decoded data and not to the number of characters in the encoded data.

listitem.para: You can inject only text files. You cannot inject binary or ZIP files into a new build.
The maxPersonality absolute limit defines the maximum number of file path and content pairs that you can supply. The compute provider determines this value.
The maxPersonalitySize absolute limit is a byte limit that is guaranteed to apply to all images in the deployment. Providers can set additional per-image personality limits.

section.para: The file injection might not occur until after the server is built and booted.

During file injection, any existing files that match files in the request are renamed to include the BAK extension appended with a time stamp. For example, if the /etc/passwd file exists, it is backed up as /etc/passwd.bak.1246036261.5785.

After file injection, only system administrators can access personality files. For example, on Linux, all files have root as the owner and the root group as the group owner, and allow only user and group read access (chmod 440).

In a hybrid environment, the underlying implementation might not control the IP address of a server. Instead, the access IP address might be part of the dedicated hardware; for example, a router/NAT device. In this case, the addresses provided by the implementation cannot actually be used to access the server (from outside the local LAN). Here, a separate access address might be assigned at creation time to provide access to the server. This address might not be directly bound to a network interface on the server and might not necessarily appear when you query the server addresses. Nonetheless, clients that must access the server directly are encouraged to do so through an access address.

section.title: Servers multiple create (servers)
section.para: Creates one or more servers.

Optionally, you can set "return_reservation_id": "True" in the request body to request that a reservation ID be returned instead of the newly created instance information. With this parameter, the response shows only the reservation ID.

section.title: Servers actions (servers, action)
section.para: Performs actions on a server. Specify the action in the request body.

section.title: Servers admin actions (servers, action)
section.para: Administrators only. Performs actions on a server. Specify the action in the request body.

section.title: Servers diagnostics (servers, diagnostics)
section.para: Gets the usage data for a server.

section.title: Servers IPs (servers, ips)
section.para: Lists the IP addresses assigned to an instance or shows details for an IP address.

section.title: Server metadata (servers, metadata)
section.para: Lists metadata, creates or replaces one or more metadata items, and updates one or more metadata items for a server.
Shows details for, creates or replaces, and updates a metadata item, by key, for a server.

section.title: Servers action (servers, os-instance-actions)
section.para: Permits all users to list available server actions for a server. Permits administrators to get details for a server action for a server.

section.title: Port interfaces (servers, os-interface)
section.para: Creates a port interface and uses it to attach a port to a server and detaches a port interface from a server. Also, lists all port interfaces and shows details for a port interface.

section.title: Servers password (servers, os-server-password)
section.para: Gets the encrypted administrative password. Also, clears the encrypted administrative password for a server, which removes it from the metadata server.

section.title: Servers virtual interfaces (servers, os-virtual-interfaces)
section.para: Lists virtual interfaces for a server instance.

section.title: Flavors with extended attributes (flavors)
section.para: Shows information about flavors.

section.title: Flavors access (flavors, os-flavor-access, action)
section.para: Provides flavor access support.

section.title: Flavors extra-specs (flavors, os-flavor-extra-specs)
section.para: Lists, creates, deletes, and updates the extra-specs or keys for a flavor.

section.title: Flavors manage (flavors, os-flavor-manage)
section.para: Creates and deletes flavors.

section.title: Keypairs (keypairs)
section.para: Generates, imports, and deletes SSH keys.

section.title: Limits (limits)
section.para: Shows all global and rate limit information.

section.title: Extensions (extensions)
section.para: Lists the available extensions and shows details for an extension, by alias.

section.title: Images
section.para: Lists, gets details for, and deletes images. Also sets, lists, gets details for, and deletes image metadata.

An image is a collection of files that you use to create and rebuild a server. By default, operators provide pre-built operating system images. You can also create custom images. See Compute server actions.
If you set the image size policy in the policy.json file, the OS-EXT-IMG-SIZE:size extended attribute is visible.

section.title: Image metadata
section.para: Shows details for, sets, updates, and deletes image metadata or metadata items.

section.title: Guest agents (os-agents)
section.para: Creates, lists, updates, and deletes guest agent builds. Use guest agents to access files on the disk, configure networking, or run other applications or scripts in the guest while the agent runs. This hypervisor-specific extension is not currently enabled for KVM. Use of guest agents is possible only if the underlying service provider uses the Xen driver.

section.title: Host aggregates (os-aggregates, action)
section.para: Creates and manages host aggregates. An aggregate assigns metadata to groups of compute nodes. Aggregates are only visible to the cloud provider.

section.title: Assisted volume snapshots (os-assisted-volume-snapshots)
section.para: Creates and deletes snapshots through an emulator/hypervisor. The qcow2 file format is supported.
An internal snapshot that lacks storage such as NFS or GlusterFS can use an emulator/hypervisor to add the snapshot feature.

section.title: Availability zones (os-availability-zone)
section.para: Gets availability zone information.

section.title: Bare metal nodes (os-baremetal-nodes)
section.para: Bare metal nodes.

section.title: Servers with block device mapping format (servers, os-block-device-mapping)
section.para: Creates a server with a block device mapping.

section.title: Cells (os-cells, capacities)
section.para: Adds neighbor cells, lists neighbor cells, and gets the capabilities of the local cell.

section.title: Root certificates (os-certificates)
section.para: Creates and shows details for a root certificate.

section.title: Cloudpipe (os-cloudpipe)
section.para: Manages virtual VPNs for projects.

section.title: Server consoles (servers, os-consoles, os-console-auth-token)
section.para: Manages server consoles.

section.title: Fixed IPs (os-fixed-ips)
section.para: Shows data for a fixed IP, such as host name, CIDR, and address. Also, reserves and frees a fixed IP address.

section.title: Floating IP DNS records (os-floating-ip-dns)
section.para: Manages DNS records associated with IP addresses allocated by the floating IPs extension. Requests are dispatched to a DNS driver selected at startup.

section.title: Floating IP pools (os-floating-ip-pools)
section.para: Manages groups of floating IPs.

section.title: Floating IPs (os-floating-ips)
section.para: Lists floating IP addresses that are associated with a project. Also, creates (allocates) a floating IP address for a project, shows floating IP address details, and deletes (deallocates) a floating IP address from a project.

A pool of floating IP addresses, configured by the cloud administrator, is available in OpenStack Compute. The project quota defines the maximum number of floating IP addresses that you can allocate to the project. After you allocate a floating IP address for a project, you can:

listitem.para: Add (associate) the floating IP address with an instance in the project. Only one floating IP address can be associated with an instance at a time.
Remove (disassociate) the floating IP address from an instance in the project.
Delete, or deallocate, a floating IP from the project, which automatically deletes any associations for that IP address.

section.title: Floating IPs bulk (os-floating-ips-bulk)
section.para: (nova-network only) Bulk-creates, deletes, and lists floating IPs. Default pool name is nova.
To view available pools, use the os-floating-ip-pools extension.

section.title: Ping instances (os-fping)
section.para: Pings instances and reports which ones are alive.

section.title: Hosts (os-hosts)
section.para: Manages physical hosts.

section.title: Hypervisors (os-hypervisors)
section.para: Lists all hypervisors, shows summary statistics for all hypervisors over all compute nodes, shows details for a hypervisor, and shows the uptime for a hypervisor.

section.title: Instance usage audit log (os-instance-usage-audit-log)
section.para: Administrator only. Monitors task logs.

section.title: Migrations (os-migrations)
section.para: Shows data on migrations.

section.title: Networks (os-networks)
section.para: Creates, lists, shows information for, and deletes networks.
Adds network to a project, disassociates a network from a project, and disassociates a project from a network.
Associates host with and disassociates host from a network.

section.title: Quota class (os-quota-class-sets)
section.para: Provides quota classes management support.

section.title: Quota sets (os-quota-sets)
section.para: Permits administrators, depending on policy settings, to view quotas for a project and view and update default quotas.

section.title: Security groups (os-security-groups)
section.para: Lists, shows information for, creates, and deletes security groups.

section.title: Rules for default security group (os-security-group-default-rules)
section.para: Lists, shows information for, and creates default security group rules.

section.title: Rules for security group (os-security-group-rules)
section.para: Creates and deletes security group rules.

section.title: Create external events (os-server-external-events)
section.para: Creates one or more external events. Each event is dispatched to a server instance.

section.title: Server groups (os-server-groups)
section.para: Lists, shows information for, creates, and deletes server groups.

section.title: Manage services (os-services)
section.para: Lists all or only disabled Compute services for all hosts in a tenant. Logs information for disabled services. Enables or disables scheduling for, forces down, unsets the forced-down state of, or deletes a service.

section.title: Usage reports (os-simple-tenant-usage)
section.para: Reports usage statistics on compute and storage resources.

section.title: Project networks (os-tenant-networks)
section.para: Creates, lists, shows information for, and deletes project networks.

section.title: Volume extension (os-volumes, os-snapshots)
section.para: Manages volumes and snapshots for use with the Compute API.
